Prolemur simus, also known as the greater bamboo lemur, is a species of lemur endemic to the island of Madagascar. It is a medium-sized primate that belongs to the family Lemuriformes.

The Prolemur simus is characterized by its large size, with an average body length of around 60 cm and a weight of approximately 2.5 kg. It has a distinctive black and white coloration, with a black face, ears, and limbs, and a white body and tail. The species is known for its specialized diet, which consists primarily of bamboo, with a particular preference for the young shoots and leaves.

Prolemur simus is considered one of the rarest and most endangered primates in the world, with a population estimated to be fewer than 500 individuals. It faces various threats, including habitat loss, fragmentation, and hunting, which have contributed to its declining numbers. Conservation efforts are underway to protect this unique species and its fragile habitat in the forests of Madagascar.
